cs.umass.edu.myactivitiestoolkit.services

Class AccelerometerService

  • java.lang.Object
    • Service
      • cs.umass.edu.myactivitiestoolkit.services.SensorService
        • cs.umass.edu.myactivitiestoolkit.services.AccelerometerService
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    edu.umass.cs.MHLClient.client.ConnectionStateHandler

    public class AccelerometerService
extends SensorService
    This service is responsible for collecting the accelerometer data on the phone. It is an ongoing foreground service that will run even when your application is not running. Note, however, that a process of your application will still be running! The sensor service will receive sensor events in the onSensorChanged(SensorEvent) method defined in the SensorEventListener interface.

    ASSIGNMENT 0 (Data Collection & Visualization) : In this assignment, you will display and visualize the accelerometer readings and send the data to the server. In onSensorChanged(SensorEvent), you should send the data to the main UI using the method broadcastAccelerometerReading(long, float[]). You should also use the SensorService.mClient object to send data to the server. You can confirm it works by checking that both the local and server-side plots are updating (make sure your html script is running on your machine!).

    ASSIGNMENT 1 (Step Detection) : In this assignment, you will detect steps using the accelerometer sensor. You will design both a local step detection algorithm and a server-side (Python) step detection algorithm. Your algorithm should look for peaks and account for the fact that humans generally take steps every 0.5 - 2.0 seconds. Your local and server-side algorithms may be functionally identical, or you may choose to take advantage of other Python tools/libraries to improve performance. Call your local step detection algorithm from onSensorChanged(SensorEvent).

    To listen for messages from the server, register a MessageReceiver with the SensorService.mClient and override the MessageReceiver.onMessageReceived(JSONObject) method to handle the message appropriately. The data will be received as a JSONObject, which you can parse to acquire the step count reading.

    We have provided you with the reading computed by the Android built-in step detection algorithm as an example and a ground-truth reading that you may use for comparison. Note that although the built-in algorithm has empirically been shown to work well, it is not perfect and may be sensitive to the phone orientation. Also note that it does not update the step count immediately, so don't be surprised if the step count increases suddenly by a lot!

    ASSIGNMENT 2 (Activity Detection) : In this assignment, you will classify the user's activity based on the accelerometer data. The only modification you should make to the mobile app is to register a listener which will parse the activity from the acquired JSONObject and update the UI. The real work, that is your activity detection algorithm, will be running in the Python script and acquiring data from the server.
    See Also:
    android.app.Service, Foreground Service, SensorEventListener#onSensorChanged(SensorEvent), SensorEvent, MobileIOClient

      • onSensorChanged

        public void onSensorChanged(SensorEvent event)
        This method is called when we receive a sensor reading. We will be interested in this method primarily.

        Assignment 0 : Your job is to send the accelerometer readings to the server as you receive them. Use the SensorService.mClient from the base class SensorService to communicate with the data collection server. Specifically look at MobileIOClient.sendSensorReading(SensorReading).

        We will be sending AccelerometerReadings. When instantiating an AccelerometerReading, pass in your user ID, which is accessible from the base sensor service, your device type and your device identifier, as well as the timestamp and values of the sensor event.

        Note you may leave the device identifier a blank string. For the device type, you can use "MOBILE".

        You also want to broadcast the accelerometer reading to the UI. You can do this by calling broadcastAccelerometerReading(long, float[]).
        See Also:
        AccelerometerReading, SensorReading, MobileIOClient, SensorEvent, broadcastAccelerometerReading(long, float[])

      • onAccuracyChanged

        public void onAccuracyChanged(Sensor sensor,
                              int accuracy)

      • broadcastAccelerometerReading

        public void broadcastAccelerometerReading(long timestamp,
                                          float[] accelerometerReadings)
        Broadcasts the accelerometer reading to other application components, e.g. the main UI.
        Parameters:
        accelerometerReadings - the x, y, and z accelerometer readings

      • broadcastAndroidStepCount

        public void broadcastAndroidStepCount(int stepCount)
        Broadcasts the step count computed by the Android built-in step detection algorithm to other application components, e.g. the main UI.

      • broadcastLocalStepCount

        public void broadcastLocalStepCount(int stepCount)
        Broadcasts the step count computed by your step detection algorithm to other application components, e.g. the main UI.

      • broadcastStepDetected

        public void broadcastStepDetected(long timestamp,
                                  float[] values)
        Broadcasts a step event to other application components, e.g. the main UI. Use this if you would like to visualize the detected step on the accelerometer signal.
